channel.title: jimgrisham tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from jimgrisham.

item.description: @Grafton1768 @67465094A350 @kamilkazani Call his bluff, smartly. He says @NATO firing on #Russia will start #WWIII. Put #Russia in a position to have to either shoot first (and start WWIII themselves first) or relent. Bullies are only strong when unchallenged. Teachers break up a fight by standing in the middle. 1/
@kamilkazani Thank you for all of your writings - both the analysis and historical context are greatly appreciated!
Another great thread of historical analysis from @kamilkazani: https://t.co/PAfSfd3sfg
@AirLogic633 @UAWeapons Maybe it helps gripping against snow/mud/water at low forward speeds, like so many tiny claws?
@blowdart Eliminate time zones altogether? People (and computers) could refer to everything in either local solar time or in #UTC.
@just_conn @AlexandraDixon @IlyaMatveev_ https://t.co/wT5d2MzHpz

@mustin_burt @JMiguel_daniels @DannyJasso7 @POTUS That should be a mostly fixed price per gallon, though, not a percentage. (except that gasoline delivery tanker trucks still use inflated-cost diesel fuel, so there is an intrinsic feedback loop that will always tend to cause short-term increases quicker than decreases)

@dehrin99 @koolynx_ @SamRamani2 Putin has been significantly tightening the screws on the Tatars in recent years, so there may be newfound disapproval by Turkey in general (i.e. even without the recent escalation of the Ukraine invasion)?

@micro_cabbage (Twitter is acting up right now; didn’t intend to reply to your photo of the TRIDENT capsules??) I was referring to the possible re-use of ICBM-style tech on the Iskander systems; agreeing with your comment that it seemed overly complex for the mission. Then again, it’s working.

@micro_cabbage If you realize that your internal (secret) doctrine is that you may threaten nuclear strikes from time to time but never actually be dumb enough to launch them, then that kind of technology re-use isn’t really risking anything at all. (Esp. with NATO THAAD/‘Aegis Ashore’ panic)

@micro_cabbage @GrumpyBadger5 @atomicthumbs @lucky_591008 @CAT_UXO Why innovate when you can just re-use something previously developed/tested for a more complex missile system? (Anything developed in the current, apparently corrupt, defense environment risks realization as the proverbial ‘bomb casing filled with used pinball machine parts’.)

@GrumpyBadger5 @StretchJourno @CAT_UXO A thread elsewhere suggested these are likely re-used from nuclear-armed versions of the missiles, so a decades-old design might make sense. There even could be overlap with decoys used with their ICBMs… why re-invent the wheel if you’ve already got something in production?

“Discussing how #Russia is governed we talk a lot about politics, ideology, religion. And yet, we pay too little attention to the economy of power. Russian regimes typically focus on two tasks: 1Producing tradable goods (=raw materials) 2Exporting them” #history #Muscovy https://t.co/zO5m6A1Ihp
@30de2e4d6c4f416 @Osinttechnical They’re likely never leaving Russian airspace.

@Lifaccordng2kat @juliaioffe Industrial demand is the most significant. For individuals with the option, for example, perhaps:
- fewer discretionary driving vacations (or vacations closer to home) - carpooling to work - leaving / later earlier to avoid traffic - using a more fuel-efficient vehicle
@PLT_cheater @Emmy_Trashfire @AscendingRamona Hey, that sounds kind of like what happened when SSL certificates became inexpensive (and eventually free)!

@WildGoo69031318 @juliaioffe We’re not importing gas, though, we’re importing oil. Any effects will be spread against all users of the refined products, and more elastic end-users (e.g. aluminum smelters) will likely cause prices to stabilize before actions by more inelastic gasoline users.
@KevinRothrock @YaleSOM Those that won’t close for whatever reason should be lobbied to _at least_ donate any profits earned in Russia since the start of the war…
